entry.title: Combined summary - Protocol changes
entry.summary: The context discusses contracts and their benefits, which are transactions that allow for lower trust in certain types of transactions. Contracts enable people to fund new things without the need for a trusted middleman to collect pledges and aggregate them, reducing fees. They can be entirely done with software, allowing artists and game programmers to run some software on their website. Some contract protocols require one party in a set to re-issue transactions without interacting with other parties. This feature allows for particular types of contracts that take place on the negotiating table of the network's memory pool. The conversation also delves into the complexities of sequence numbers and how they are used in certain contract protocols to allow for re-issuing transactions without requiring all participants to re-sign or altering the original input signatures. However, changing inputs beyond scripts is limited, and certain conditions must be met before a contract can move from the memory pool into a chain. The article also talks about TX filtering and its benefit, suggesting that it is better to get only relevant transactions and merkle branches instead of downloading every block. Finally, the point of added complexity in contracts is debated, with some considering it a useful feature while others have their doubts. Overall, the discussion provides valuable insights into contracts, their benefits, and how they work.
